Last year, the Food and Drug Administration stepped into a new territory.
It approved a heart failure medication called BiDil, specifically for African-Americans.
BiDil is the only race-specific drug on the U.S.
market.
But now, more than a year since the drug's release, sales are dismal.
Debate over the race in medicine question continues.
From member station KQED in San Francisco, Sarah Varney reports.
Researchers don't know why, but African-Americans have much higher rates of heart failure than other racial and ethnic groups.
That's why black advocacy groups greeted BiDil with such fanfare.

An early study seemed to suggest the drug worked better in African-Americans, and a follow-up clinical trial showed that when used with standard therapies, BiDil sharply reduced deaths from heart failure.
But because the makers of BiDil included only self-identified African-Americans in the drug trial, the FDA approved the drug only for blacks.

BiDil came out in July 2005.
After lackluster sales, the maker of BiDil, Nitromed, ran radio ads in select markets this fall.
The firm also worked with black community groups to get the word out.
But so far, Nitromed says only 2 to 3 percent of black heart failure patients are using the drug.
Instead, doctors are prescribing the cheaper generic components that make up BiDil.
Health insurers, too, have balked at paying for a brand-name drug when there's a lower-cost alternative.
That hasn't sat well with the NAACP.
It's a serious enough issue that we are not going to sit back and just let it happen or fail to happen.
NAACP Health Committee member Juan Cofield has urged some of the nation's largest health plans to offer BiDil, saying the move would save lives.
That came after the NAACP and Nitromed formed a $1.5 million partnership to help blacks improve their health habits and access to medical care.
Cofield says BiDil is just a small part of the NAACP's health efforts.

But some medical ethicists question cheerleading a drug that implies race is in some way biological, a logic often used by white supremacists to explain why some minorities don't do well in school or have more violence in their neighborhoods.
That really can lead us down the wrong path in terms of trying to provide good healthcare for everyone.

Stanford University ethicist, Sandra Soo-Jin Lee, makes this point: if drugs are targeted to specific races, it can suggest a racial or ethnic group's health problems - like lower life expectancy and infant mortality among blacks - are genetic rather than social or environmental, which makes doing something about the problem less of a priority.
Berkeley, California-based cardiologist Dr. Duane Stephens says environment is important.
He says heart failure is higher in blacks in part because the underlying causes - like stress about finances or safe housing - often aren't detected early enough.
Blacks in this country and Hispanics and minorities in general, access to healthcare is a problem.
Adequate healthcare is the problem.
Insurance is a problem.
So many patients tend to go for a longer period of time before they actually enter the healthcare system.
That said, Dr. Stephens contends his African-American heart failure patients do seem to respond better to BiDil than his non-black patients, and he has no idea why.
To totally dismiss a genetic - if you will, in general - or possibly a race-based difference may be missing the mark.
A growing number of medical researchers agree.
University of California San Francisco Medical School Professor Esteban Burchard says people in one racial or ethnic group tend to share a common ancestry.
You will find that African-Americans in the United States are on average 80 percent African and 20 percent European.
Burchard contends that ancestral makeup brings with it genetic baggage that interacts with diet, exercise, income and many other factors.
And in some way, that endlessly complicated hodgepodge may account for different drug response or susceptibility to disease.
What we all know already is that drugs are not going to work the same across every single population, just like they don't work the same between men and women, between young and old.
So I think where we're going is that we are going to become more conscientious of some of these differences and include them into our decision making when prescribing medications.
But I don't think it's ever going to be cut and dry that you're this race, so you get this drug.

Nitromed would also like to know if there are certain genes that might explain why blacks appear to respond better to their wonder drug, and perhaps develop a genetic test to identify other potential customers.
